perturbation.original_text: Customer acknowledges and agrees that Changepoint or licensors of Changepoint shall retain all right, title and interest in and to the Licensed Materials and all copies thereof, including, without limitation, the Intellectual Property Rights therein, and that nothing herein transfers or conveys to Customer any ownership right, title or interest in or to the Licensed Materials or to any copy thereof or any license right with respect to same not expressly granted herein, including, without limitation, with respect to the Intellectual Property Rights therein.
perturbation.changed_text: Customer acknowledges that Changepoint or licensors of Changepoint shall retain all right, title and interest in and to the Licensed Materials and all copies thereof. Nothing herein transfers or conveys to Customer any ownership right, title or interest in or to the Licensed Materials or to any copy thereof.
perturbation.explanation: The original text explicitly protects Changepoint's intellectual property rights. The modified text removes the phrase 'including, without limitation, the Intellectual Property Rights therein,' weakening Changepoint's protection of its IP, creating a legal contradiction because intellectual property rights are legally protected and enforceable. This weakens the protection of Changepoint's intellectual property, potentially violating intellectual property laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Intellectual Property Law (e.g., Copyright Act, Patent Act)

perturbation.original_text: Changepoint will defend or (at its option) settle, any claim or action brought against Customer to the extent that it is based on a claim that the Licensed Materials infringe any copyright, patent, trade secret or trademark enforceable in the United States of America of any third person (an "Infringement Claim") and will indemnify Customer against damages and costs awarded against Customer by a court of competent jurisdiction by final order from which no appeal is taken or the time for appealing has expired, provided that Customer notifies Changepoint promptly in writing of same, and provided further that Customer permits Changepoint to control the litigation and to defend, compromise or settle the claim and provides all available information, assistance and authority to enable Changepoint to do so. Changepoint shall not be liable to reimburse Customer for any compromise or settlement made by Customer without Changepoint's prior written consent, or for any legal fees or expenses incurred by Customer in connection with such claim. Customer shall have no authority to settle any claim on behalf of Changepoint.
perturbation.changed_text: Changepoint will defend any claim or action brought against Customer based on a claim that the Licensed Materials infringe any copyright, patent, trade secret or trademark of any third person (an "Infringement Claim") and will indemnify Customer against damages and costs. Customer notifies Changepoint in writing of same, and Customer permits Changepoint to control the litigation and to defend the claim and provides information to enable Changepoint to do so. Customer shall not be liable to reimburse Customer for any compromise or settlement made by Customer without Changepoint's consent, or for any legal fees or expenses incurred by Customer in connection with such claim. Customer shall have no authority to settle any claim on behalf of Changepoint.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text removes critical limitations from Changepoint's indemnification obligations.  The original text limited indemnification to infringements 'enforceable in the United States of America', this is removed. The original required 'a court of competent jurisdiction by final order from which no appeal is taken or the time for appealing has expired,' creating a stricter criteria, which is now gone. The removal of 'at its option) settle' forces Changepoint to defend every claim which is not a realistic practice. These omissions create a legal contradiction with standard practices regarding the scope and limitations of indemnification clauses.

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of New York without reference to its conflict or choice of law rules or principles. Customer hereby submits to the non-exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of the State of New York for any legal action arising out of this Agreement or the performance of the obligations hereunder or thereunder. This Agreement shall be deemed to be made in the State of New York, and Customer agrees not to commence any action, suit or proceeding against Changepoint or any affiliate of Changepoint or any of their employees, officers or directors in any jurisdiction other than the State of New York.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of a jurisdiction determined by Changepoint. Customer submits to the jurisdiction of courts chosen by Changepoint for any legal action arising out of this Agreement. Customer agrees not to commence any action against Changepoint or any of their employees, officers or directors in any jurisdiction without Changepoint's approval.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause specifies New York law as governing and provides for non-exclusive jurisdiction in New York courts. The modified clause allows Changepoint to unilaterally determine the governing law and jurisdiction, restricting Customer's ability to seek legal remedies in a fair and predictable forum. The addition of 'without Changepoint's approval' is a blatant violation of civil procedure, where all people have the right to sue in court. This creates a legal contradiction with fundamental principles of due process and fairness in legal proceedings, particularly if Changepoint chooses a jurisdiction unfavorable to the Customer.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Due Process Clause of the U.S. Constitution (or equivalent in other jurisdictions), principles of contract law regarding fair forum selection.
